title.narrative: Hivos Den regionala fonden: ASRHR i södra Afrika
Hivos Regional Fund: ASRHR in the Southern Africa Region

description.narrative:
Hivos Hub för Södra Afrika har ansökt till Sveriges regionala SRHR-team i Lusaka om finansiering om 78 miljoner kronor för att stödja Hivos regionala SRHR-fond för att stärka ungdomars sexuella och l reproduktiva hälsa och rättigheter i södra och östra Afrika under perioden 2017-2021.
Hivos regionala SRHR-fond har som målsättning "Förbättrade rättigheter och tillgång till kvalitativa SRHR-tjänster på ett säkert, rättvist sätt för alla medborgare, särskilt kvinnor, flickor och nyckelgrupper och särskilt utsatta personer ”. Syftet med det föreslagna projektet är att komplettera Hivos regionala program med ett målinriktat tillvägagångssätt för ungdomar och deras SRHR genom att stärka ungdomsorganisationers förmåga att samla evidens och påverka regionala SRHR-policy. Hivos SRHR-fond kommer att bedriva bidragsverksamhet som inriktas på fem (5) områden: Kapacitetsförstärkning, Kunskapshantering, Påverkansarbete, Samordning och sammankallande och behovsbaserad finansiering. Genom inriktning på dessa områden strävar interventionen efter att uppnå följande resultat:
1. Att politik och policy i regionen bättre svarar upp mot SRHR-behov hos ungdomar. 2. Att regionala hälsosystemen bättre möter nya kunskaper och information kring SRHR hos unga. 3. Att regionala hälsoorganisationer i större utsträckning engagerar ungdomsledda/ungdomsfokuserade organisationer 4. Stärkt ungdomsledd/ungdomsfokuserad SRHR-rörelse i regionen 5. Upprätt en fond för strategiska och behovsbaserade bidrag för att underlätta engagemang i regionala SRHR-initiativ
Projektpersonal kommer att vara baserad i Zimbabwe (huvudkontor) och Sydafrika för att överse genomförandet av projektet. Hivos Hub för södra Afrika har också landkontor i Malawi och Zambia. På grund av karaktären av Hivos arbete kommer den exakta placeringen av mottagare av bidrag från den regionala fonden bero på vilka organisationer som söker och sedermera beviljas stöd.

Hivos Southern Africa Hub has applied to Sweden’s Regional SRHR Team in Lusaka for funding of 78 million SEK to support Hivos Regional Sexual Reproductive Health and Rights Fund (RSRHR) strengthen Adolescent Sexual Reproductive Health and Rights in Southern Africa, and to an extent East Africa, during the period 2017-2021.
The current Hivos RSRHR Programme Fund has as its goal the “Improved realisation of rights and access to quality SRHR services in a safe, fair and equitable manner by all citizens/people in the region, particularly women, girls and key populations/marginalised groups”. The purpose of the proposed project is to supplement Hivos' regional programme with a targeted approach to adolescent and youth SRHR through strengthening the capacity of young people and their organisations to gather the evidence and to influence regional SRHR policy and programmatic agendas. Hivos RSRHR Fund, through their grant making approach, will undertake grant making activities focused on five (5) areas: Capacity Strengthening, Knowledge management, Advocacy and Awareness Raising, Coordination and Convening and Needs Based Funding. Through focus on these areas the intervention seeks to achieve the following outcomes:
1. Increased regional policy and service delivery responsiveness to the SRHR needs of adolescents and youth 2. Regional health system increasingly responds to new and emerging knowledge and data on ASRH 3. Regional health structures engage more substantively with youth-led /youth-focused organisations 4. Strengthened youth-led / youth-focused ASRHR movement in the region 5. A Fund for strategic and responsive grant-making is in place to facilitate engagement in strategic regional SRHR initiatives
Project staff will be located in Zimbabwe (head office) ane South Africa to oversee implementation of the project. Hivos Southern Africa Hub also has country offices in Malawi and Zambia. Due to the nature of Hivos work, the exact location of sub-grantees will only be known once calls are made and grantees are selected and awarded.

In 2017 Sweden's Regional SRHR team approved a four-year project proposal submitted by Hivos Southern Africa Hub. The project aims to build and strengthen strategic ASRHR partnerships and collaboration at the regional level, and to achieve outcomes that are inter-connected, mutually reinforcing and linked to the health and well-being needs of young people and adolescents in Eastern and Southern Africa (ESA). By December 2021, the project is expected to have achieved stronger and more coordinated youth-led and youth-focused civil society in Southern and East Africa that can promote, address and advance Adolescent and Youth Sexual and Reproductive Health Rights (ASRHR) and its interconnection to HIV at the regional level. The project was conceptualized to strengthen interventions on ASRHR in Southern Africa and further into East Africa with the aim of improving access to SRHR for young people and adolescents.
The specific objectives of the project are:
Objective 1: Capacity strengthening - Youth-led and/or youth-focused organizations are trained, mentored and upskilled in all areas of organizational and programmatic capacity to enable them to promote and advocate for improved access for adolescents and youth to SRHR services.
Objective 2: Knowledge management - There is improved knowledge sharing, networking and data collection on SRHR in the region by youth-led and/or youthfocused organisations and individuals, as well as increased capacity for youth-driven research.
Objective 3: Advocacy and Awareness Raising - Youth-led and/or youth-focused organisations have improved capacity to conceptualise, design and coordinate joint ASRHR advocacy and awareness-raising campaigns in the region. Objective 4: Convening and Coordination - Youth-led and/or youth focused organisations have enhanced capacity to coordinate SRHR activities and convene spaces through integrated and inter linked activities, including with similary organisations in East Africa.
Objective Five: Special Initiatives: Responsive Grant Making The intervention will also make provision for a Special Initiatives Fund to support individual or organizational participation in key forums and strategic meetings to advocate and advance SRHR for all, support to innovative interventions, support to evidence based research, as well to respond to unexpected situations requiring immediate response in the broader SRHR realm.
The contribution is all tied together by grant making which serves as a Critical Enabler - serving as the mechanism that funds an integrated set of strategies, activities and approaches that aim to improve the accessibility, acceptability, uptake, equitable coverage, quality, effectiveness and efficiency of ASRHR interventions and services.

description.narrative:
Summary of results for 2020: Overall, project activities were implemented in six (7) countries namely; Malawi, Kenya, Uganda, South Africa, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe. A total of 9 sub grants were awarded during period under review for the total amount of $ 744,445 out of the $1 000 000 allocated. 78% of the grants were under the strategic grants category. Capacity strengthening and the Youth Research Academy (YRA) both made up 11% of the grant portfolio. 34% of the partners were located in Kenya; 33% in Zimbabwe; 11% in Tanzania, Uganda and Malawi. Thematic focus was on access to adolescent SRHR information and services (3 projects), child & forced marriages (2 projects); ending early & unintended pregnancies (2 projects); access to safe & legal abortion (2 projects); and HIV/AIDS & other STIs (2 projects). Additionally, there single projects that focused on LGBTI sexual health & rights; Universal Health Coverage (UHC) and Sexual & Gender Based Violence (SGBV). Adolescents in general were the key beneficiaries for all the nine partner/projects. Notable to add that one project included Young people living with disabilities; one project focused on refugee youth and one project included LGBTI Youth.
Results per objective:
Objective 1: Capacity strengthening: Youth-led and/or youth-focused organizations are trained, mentored and upskilled in all areas of organizational and programmatic capacity to enable them to promote and advocate for improved access for adolescents and youth to SRHR services.
- Strengthened capacity of 16 youth led organisations spread across 4 countries (Malawi, Kenya, Zambia and Zimbabwe) to design and implement ASRHR programmes and undertake advocacy for improved access to ASRH. -The 16 youth led organisations have had enhanced capacities in areas of organisational and financial management; advocacy; research; resource mobilisation and project management via the organisational development consultant. -In regards to strategic grantees providing support and mentorship to the capacity strengthening grantees: SAT Zambia continued to provide coaching and mentoring to Resilient Youth for Change (YOCA) in its capacity as the fiscal host, supporting YOCA with all aspects of financial and programme management. Network for Adolescent and Youth of Africa (NAYA) closely worked with Dream Achievers Youth Organisation (DAYO) in developing various national and county level Adolescent SRHR Frameworks. Youth advocates Zimbabwe (YAZ) as a strategic grant partner collaborated with DAYO on convening an Age of Consent stakeholders consultative meeting in Kenya. YAZ also collaborated with and supported Zambia Youth Platform (ZYP) in hosting a national engagement meeting on access to health services for youth in Zambia. SAT Zimbabwe continues in its role as the fiscal host to Deaf Women Included (DWI) supporting DWI in financial management and organisational strengthening. The Graca Machel Trust also continued to support Zambia Youth Platform (ZYP) and Alliance for Accountability Advocates (AAA) Zambia with the technical skills and support for all their ASRH accountability work.
Objective 2: Knowledge management: There is improved knowledge sharing, networking and data collection on SRHR in the region by youth-led and/or youthfocused organisations and individuals, as well as increased capacity for youth-driven research.
- Hivos hosted a regional webinar on the current state of age of consent in eastern and southern Africa on 13th October, 2020. The total participation was 62 from across the region. A number of recommendations were made at the close of the meeting regarding the way forward in the different country contexts as well as laws and policies guiding the age of consent debate at regional level. -Youth organisations have increasingly undertaken research to provide evidence for improved access to adolescent SRHR information and services. For example, Uganda Youth and Adolescent Health Forum (UYAHF) undertook a rapid assessment of young peoples experiences, challenges and best practices on demand, access and utilization of youth-friendly contraceptive services in Mbale district of Uganda. This research has led to the improvement in the provision of Adolescent SRH services for Youth in Mbale district in Uganda. - Through support from Hivos, Action Aid Zambia has supported 19 youth research champions in increasing their capacity to undertake research.
Objective 3: Advocacy and Awareness Raising: Youth-led and/or youth-focused organisations have improved capacity to conceptualise, design and coordinate joint ASRHR advocacy and awareness-raising campaigns in the region.
- As a result of the intervention, a number of youth organisations have increasingly engaged their duty bearers in ensuring that adolescent SRHR needs and services are prioritised. For example, Zambia Youth Platform (ZYP) held a series of consultative meetings with the ministry of health officials; Dream Achievers Youth Organisation in Kenya has continued to engage the Mombasa county officials in ensuring that the 5 Year adolescent Health Strategy is fully resourced and implemented. Similarly, Alliance for Accountability Advocates Zambia (AAAZ) has continued to engage with the Ministry of Health Zambia to push for more accountability in resourcing for adolescent SRHR. In Kenya a Youth refugee through the HIAS implanted project has been accorded a seat on the Nairobi county Health advisory committee representing Youth refugees. -Hivos continues to lead conversation on the Age of Consent and supported its partners and other stakeholders like UNICEF Zimbabwe to conceptualize strategies aimed at addressing issues around Age of Consent. -Young people living with disabilities have shown increased self-urgency to push for their own Adolescent SRHR agenda. In Zimbabwe, Deaf Women Included (DWI) successfully convened a Dialogue on Health N Partnerships towards a disability inclusiveness health strategy with representatives from the Ministry of health present. - Hivos provided technical support for the Zambia Ministry of Health Safe Abortion Advisory Group (SAAG) annual review meeting. The SAAG is a technical advisory group cochaired by MoH and civil society for implementation of safe abortion services and related policies. The meeting reviewed the implementation of the SAAG work plan and strategies for enhanced implementation and advocacy for 2021. The meeting was preceded by a training of members on anti-choice monitoring and countering of the opposition. -Hivos provided technical support to the Zambia Comprehensive Sexuality Education (CSE) Taskforce. The CSE Taskforce was formed to respond to calls for the suspension of the CSE curriculum in Zambia which was successful overturned by the Zambia CSE task force which is comprised of CSOs and UN agencies. Hivos chairs the resource mobilization committee of the taskforce and continues to participate in consultative meetings with the Ministry of General Education (MoGE) on the roadmap for the review of the CSE curriculum. MoGE, through cabinet, has set up a technical committee for a stakeholder review of the CSE curriculum as directed by her honour the Vice President. Objective 4: Convening and Coordination: Youth-led and/or youth focused organisations have enhanced capacity to coordinate SRHR activities and convene spaces through integrated and inter linked activities, including with similary organisations in East Africa. Althought Covid19 brought restrictions to regional travel and covening of large gatherings the intervention was able to showcase a few results: - Hivos supported Zambia Youth Platform (ZYP) to successfully convene a Regional Adolescent Health Indaba (RAHi) with young leaders from six countries. The purpose of the RAHi was to share existing best practices and research in the SADC region to support scale-up in order to improve SRHR and HIV-related service delivery for adolescents and young people in all their diversity, renew the youth commitment to support achievement of the globally agreed Fast-Track goals, transform harmful gender norms and improve SRHR and HIV outcomes for adolescents and young people.
Objective 5: Special Initiative Fund (Responsive Grant Making): Hivos a fund on behalf of Sida to support individual or organizational participation in key forums and strategic meetings to advocate and advance SRHR for all, support to innovative interventions, support to evidence based research, as well to respond to unexpected situations requiring immediate response in the broader SRHR realm.
-The fund supported eight (8) youth to attend the 4th Annual Scientific Conference on Youth & Adolescent SRHR in Kenya (4 were from DAYO and 4 from DGIK). During the conference DAYO participated in various panel discussions including a high level panel discussion on Taking Stock of ICPD25 Commitments.This Adolescent Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights Scientific Conference is held on an annual basis to provide a platform for SRHR stakeholders, actors, champions and young people to share experiences and learn new information on Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights from experts. The 2020 conference theme was Addressing the three zeroes By Prioritizing Adolescent and Young Peoples SRHR and focused on bringing together, Policy Makers , Service Providers, experts ,Grassroots Women and Girls , Men , Sexual and Gender Minority Groups, like minded civil society organizations and young people from the National, Regional and International community (Three zeroes being :(1) Zero unmet need for family planning information and services, and universal availability of quality, accessible, affordable and safe modern contraceptives; (2) Zero preventable maternal deaths and maternal morbidities, such as obstetric fistulas, by, inter alia, integrating a comprehensive package of SRH interventions, including access to safe abortion to the full extent of the law, measures for preventing and avoiding unsafe abortions, and for the provision of post-abortion care, into national UHC strategies, policies and programmes, and to protect and ensure all individuals right to bodily integrity, autonomy and reproductive rights, and to provide access to essential services in support of these rights; (3) (a) Zero sexual and gender-based violence and harmful practices, including zero child, early and forced marriage, as well as zero female genital mutilation and (b) Elimination of all forms of discrimination against all women and girls, in order to realize all individuals full socio-economic potential). -The fund received and approved 2 applications from Accountability International (AI) and Uganda Youth and Adolescents Health Forum (UYAHF). Under AI, funding will go towards the development of an Africa Covid 19 Score Card. The Africa Covid 19 Score Card aimed at producing an independent, civil society-driven analysis of the COVID-19 data for Africa, and one which connects the various issues of health, human rights, socioeconomics, and accountability to African community leaders and human rights activists. Under UYAHF, funding will go towards design of a mobile application called Pulaniki ; a mobile-based application that brings essential sexual and reproductive and maternal health products, services and information closer to the urban population 15 - 35 years.
As an organisation, Hivos was successfully awarded a Global grant by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on SRHR Strategic partnerships for the 5-year period (2020 N 2024). This programme entitled WE Lead will focus on improving the SRH outcomes of marginalized young women and girls including; young women & girls living with disability; Lesbian, Bisexual, Transgender and Intersex (LBTI) young women & girls; young women & girls living with HIV/AID and migrant or displaced young women & girls. The focus countries in Africa are Mozambique, Kenya, Uganda, Niger and Nigeria. The programme will also be implemented in the MENA and Latin America regions.
